title: Erdős Problem #180: Turán Numbers for Graph Families
description: For a finite family F of graphs, does there exist G in F such that ex(n;G) = O(ex(n;F))? Yes for non-bipartite families by Erdős-Stone. Folklore counterexample for infinite families. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #180, posed by Erdős and Simonovits [ErSi82], asks whether the Turán number of a finite graph family is always dominated by a single member. For non-bipartite families, the Erdős-Stone theorem resolves this. A folklore counterexample (star + matching) exists for infinite families.
overview.problemStatement: For a finite family F of graphs, let ex(n;F) be the maximum edges in an n-vertex F-free graph. Does there always exist G in F such that ex(n;G) = O(ex(n;F))? OPEN.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines ExFamily, ExSingle, HasDomination, and the main conjecture ErdosConjecture180. The non-bipartite case is axiomatized via Erdős-Stone. The bipartite case and folklore counterexample for infinite families are formalized.
keyInsights: The domination property asks if a single forbidden graph controls the family's extremal function
Non-bipartite case resolved by Erdős-Stone: chromatic number determines asymptotics
The bipartite case is nontrivial due to unknown Zarankiewicz-type bounds
Folklore counterexample for infinite families: star + matching
Connected to Turán-type extremal graph theory

sections.title: Part I: Turán Numbers
sections.summary: Defines turanNumber via sSup, ExSingle, ExFamily type aliases.

sections.title: Part II: The Domination Property
sections.summary: Defines HasDomination: some member's Turán number is O(family's Turán number).

sections.title: Part III: The Main Conjecture
sections.summary: Defines ErdosConjecture180: every finite family has domination. Axiom erdos_180.

sections.title: Part IV: Non-Bipartite Case (Erdős-Stone)
sections.summary: Axiom erdos_stone_domination: non-bipartite families have the domination property.

sections.title: Part V: Bipartite Case Difficulty
sections.summary: Defines BipartiteCase. Axiom folklore_counterexample_infinite for infinite families.

sections.title: Part VI: Properties
sections.summary: Axioms: family_le_members (family ≤ min of members), monotonicity.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #180 asks whether a single forbidden graph always dominates the Turán number of a finite graph family. Resolved for non-bipartite families, but open in general.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would clarify the structure of extremal functions for forbidden graph families, connecting to the Zarankiewicz problem and bipartite Turán theory.
openQuestions: Does domination hold for all finite families?
What happens for families of bipartite graphs?
Can the folklore counterexample be extended to finite families?
How does the answer depend on the structure of the family?
